author: delasy
text:
hey everyone I'm working on a boilerplate repository for my company and I have a question: so I have an Express.js backend that already has login, signup, email verification, and password reset configured, working and covered with tests.

I wanted to use Better Auth on the Next.js side in a kinda just auth-client way, where I will be not running Better Auth's migrations. So what I need from Better Auth is just this implementation of sessions (though Next.js has no database connection, only Express.js has).

The communication between Express.js and Next.js is done via access/refresh tokens, but the endpoints are not standard OAuth2 endpoints - they are custom coded.

I checked on bearer and jwt plugins and it doesn't seem to be doing what I need, and I need to use Better Auth to communicate with my Express.js from Next.js app.

What is the best way to integrate Better Auth inside my Next.js app?

author: ping__
text: Because we don't pass `forceAllowId` it means that the `id` which is generated from BA kit's side is out-dated compared to the actual `id` values in your DB, so any subsequent tables to be generated (such as account) would be generating with incorrect foreign key relations

author: angularyigs
text: I know, I just let the code flow to see what happens, but I prefer to stick as close to the core as possible so as not to have more surprises when updating later.

text: the errors you see are not actually that it's failing to insert, rather the APIs to inserting using the adapter requires you to pass `forceAllowId` in adapter.create in newer versions of BA

author: _ouariachi
text:
There are cases where email verification is not necessary or can be a strategy.

In some corporate environments with an internal network, emails are trusted by default, and verification is unnecessary.

It can also be a strategy for rapid onboarding, where users are allowed to try out the platform before verifying. Email verification is a stage where lead conversion can be reduced.

This article discusses this topic: https://medium.com/nick-lim-ux-portfolio/case-study-how-fixing-email-verification-issues-restored-our-100-task-success-rate-be79693c752b

author: cakemakerjake
text:
Two issues with the SSO plugin:
- Users can still register with a different auth method than SSO when their domain is configured, and when they do the don't get added to the organization by default. Two possible solutions:
  - Disable signing up with other methods for SSO configured domains
  - Add the ability to add them to the SSO organization anyway if the domain matches
- The SSO config is tied to user with cascade on delete, so If I set up SSO for my org, then hand over ownership to someone else and delete my account, the SSO config is deleted

author: alistarfire
text:
why is it recommended to use the api object when integrating better-auth with next.js?

RSC and Server actions
The api object exported from the auth instance contains all the actions that you can perform on the server. Every endpoint made inside Better Auth is as invocable as a function. Including plugins endpoints.

while when it comes to tanstack start, it is recommended to use the client SDK?

TanStack Start integration:
Usage tips
We recommend using the client SDK or authClient to handle authentication, rather than server actions with auth.api.

author: shifty0311
text:
Seems so.

The Problem
On Line 1297-1300 in the SAML callback handler:

better-auth\packages\sso\src\index.ts
```const¬†parsedSamlConfig¬†=¬†JSON.parse(¬†¬†¬†¬†provider.samlConfig¬†as¬†unknown¬†as¬†string,);
The issue is that provider.samlConfig might already be a parsed object rather than a JSON string, depending on your database adapter.```

The Root Cause
During provider creation (lines 622-635), the samlConfig is stored as JSON.stringify(config)
During provider retrieval, some database adapters automatically parse JSON fields, while others return them as strings
The callback handler assumes it's always a string and tries to parse it again

Is there a better way to refer to this type?

Can someone please explain how I can make `authClient` infer my custom plugin?

My plugin works fine but there is always a squiggly no matter what I do.
I can see that the RHS infers the custom plugin but the LHS doesn't:
```typescript
export const authClient = createAuthClient({
  plugins: [enhancedPasswordClient()],
});
```

I have checked that my custom plugin's server and client code seem fine:
`server.ts`
```typescript
export const enhancedPassword = () => {
  return {
    id: "enhanced-password",
    endpoints: {
      signIn: createAuthEndpoint(
        "enhanced-password/sign-in") ...
    }
  } satisfies BetterAuthPlugin
}
```

`client.ts`
```typescript
export const enhancedPasswordClient = () => {
  return {
    id: "enhanced-password",
    $InferServerPlugin: {} as ReturnType<typeof enhancedPassword>,
  } satisfies BetterAuthClientPlugin;
};
```
Thanks!

author: milyord
text:
OIDC provider: do trustedClients persist to DB, or do I still need to register/seed clients?

I‚Äôm using the OIDC provider plugin with jwt() (useJWTPlugin: true). Issuer + discovery are good; JWKS (RS256) is working. I added a trustedClients entry like:
```ts
trustedClients: [
  {
    clientId: "my-public-client",
    type: "public",
    redirectURLs: ["https://example.com/callback"],
    skipConsent: true,
    metadata: { internal: true }
  }
]
```


When the code flow hits /oauth2/token, my server logs show a DB error inserting into the access-tokens table due to a FOREIGN KEY constraint referencing the client id. My OIDC tables (e.g., oauth_applications / oauth_access_tokens or camelCase variants) were empty, which makes me think the FK expects a client row but trustedClients didn‚Äôt create one.

Questions:

Does trustedClients automatically create/persist an oauthApplication (client) row, or is it purely in-memory for consent/lookup bypass?

If it doesn‚Äôt persist, what‚Äôs the recommended way to create the client record without enabling open dynamic registration in production? (Is there a CLI/SDK helper or a standard migration/seed path?)

Is there support (or a roadmap) for Initial Access Tokens so /oauth2/register can stay protected but still allow admin-initiated dynamic registration?

For public clients, should the stored metadata include type = "public" and token_endpoint_auth_method = "none"? Any guidance on exact table/column names (snake vs camel) for manual seeding?

For context, calling POST /oauth2/register returns {"error":"invalid_token","error_description":"Authentication required for client registration"} when allowDynamicClientRegistration is false, which suggests registration is intentionally locked. I‚Äôm trying to confirm the best practice to pre-create clients in the DB for production.

<@464969494989766667> any way to revoke session in after hook. (ik ideally i should stop the session from being created in before hook but for social signin i get the email in after hook). I tried this but the cookie is still being created 

```
const clearSession = async (
  ctx: MiddlewareContext<
    MiddlewareOptions,
    AuthContext & {
      returned?: unknown;
      responseHeaders?: Headers;
    }
  >,
) => {
  // Retrieve the current session token (from the new session data or cookies)
  const cookieName = ctx.context.authCookies.sessionToken.name;
  const sessionToken =
    ctx.context.newSession?.session.token || ctx.getCookie(cookieName);

  if (sessionToken) {
    // Revoke the session on the backend
    // (Using Better Auth‚Äôs built-in revokeSession method ensures the session is removed from the database)
    await auth.api.revokeSession({
      body: { token: sessionToken },
      headers: headers(),
    });
  }

  // Clear the session token cookie.
  // If the cookie is signed, use setSignedCookie with the secret
  if (ctx.setSignedCookie && ctx.context.secret) {
    ctx.setSignedCookie(cookieName, '', ctx.context.secret, {
      maxAge: 0,
      httpOnly: true,
      secure: true,
    });
  }
};

```

author: crxn307
text:
<@464969494989766667> 
I think there is a bug with organizationHooks: beforeCreateOrganization

As we want to change the data from ctx.body. As you see, before requesting the beforeCreateOrganization we read the data from ctx.body. In beforeCreateOrganization we update the ctx.body with our new data, but on adapter.createOrganization we still use the old data (...orgData)
```ts
const {
  keepCurrentActiveOrganization: _,
  userId: __,
  ...orgData
} = ctx.body;

if (options?.organizationHooks?.beforeCreateOrganization) {
  const response =
  await options?.organizationHooks.beforeCreateOrganization({
    organization: orgData,
    user,
  });
  if (response && typeof response === "object" && "data" in response) {
    ctx.body = {
      ...ctx.body,
      ...response.data,
    };
   }
}

const organization = await adapter.createOrganization({
  organization: {
    ...orgData,
    createdAt: new Date(),
  },
});
```

author: falconizzare
text:
It's the correct behavior. Imagine a scenario.. u logged in to your website a session is created on server,, then for some reason you cleared all data of your browser,, so of course no session token is there,, so you have  to login again creating another session,, now you have two sessions on the server and u can use only one cause the previous one, it's gone from client end...

There are many other reasons that can cause the scenario and the server has no way of knowing if your user is logging in multiple times intentionally or genuinely. 

So better to redirect users on the frontend when session is valid so that they cant log in multiple times intentionally by going back.

text:
I see. If the user can submit the form or click the discord auth button multiple times then with each submission/click a new session is generated. This is because each time it's a new request and server processes it.

What you can do to prevent this is redirect the user to another page if a valid session already exists. So when in  login page, check authClient.useSession(), if it's not null and has data, that means a valid session is available and no need to login again and redirect the user to another page.

author: theuntraceable
text:
Eh. I'll be honest, it depends on what you need. 

Fastest time to ship with simplicity and have money to spare: Clerk
Get access to enterprise ready stuff (that better auth can do) at the price of $125/connection/month: WorkOS

Both those options you have to pay money at some point, can get expensive, but you should get dedicated support teams (if you're paying that much).

With better auth you own everything, you can make your own UI, no limits no flaws, all for free. Only flawed if it takes time, but there are some OSS better auth stuff like better auth ui that can help
